raw_text: Whittaker and Stenton (1988) devised rules for allocating dialogue control based on utterance types, and Walker and Whittaker (1990) utilized these rules for an analytical study on discourse segmentation
clean_text: Whittaker and Stenton (1988) devised rules for allocating dialogue control based on utterance types, and Walker and Whittaker (1990) utilized these rules for an analytical study on discourse segmentation.

raw_text: Suppose we adopt a model that maintains a single thread of control, such as that of (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988)

raw_text: Repetitions and prompts also suggest that the speaker has nothing more to say and indicate that the hearer should take over the initiative (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988)
clean_text: Repetitions and prompts also suggest that the speaker has nothing more to say and indicate that the hearer should take over the initiative (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988).

raw_text: 1988 Whittaker and Stenton (1988) proposed rules for tracking initiative based on utterance types; for example, statements, proposals,
clean_text: Whittaker and Stenton (1988) proposed rules for tracking initiative based on utterance types; for example, statements, proposals, and questions show initiative, while answers and acknowledgements do not.

citing_paper_authors: Susan E., Strayer | Peter A., Heeman
raw_text: Initiative is held by the speaker who is driving the conversation at any given point in the conversation (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988, 1The segment initiator corresponds to the initiating conversational participant (ICP) of Grosz and Sidner ' s theory
clean_text: Initiative is held by the speaker who is driving the conversation at any given point in the conversation (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988).

citing_paper_authors: Susan E., Strayer | Peter A., Heeman
raw_text: Whittaker and Stenton (1988) looked at the correlation of control boundaries to discourse markers, and Walker and Whittaker (1990) looked at anaphoric reference
clean_text: Whittaker and Stenton (1988) looked at the correlation of control boundaries to discourse markers, and Walker and Whittaker (1990) looked at anaphoric reference.

citing_paper_authors: Susan E., Strayer | Peter A., Heeman
raw_text: Initiative coding In our study, the rst author coded initiative using the annotation scheme of Whittaker and Stenton (1988)
clean_text: In our study, the first author coded initiative using the annotation scheme of Whittaker and Stenton (1988).

citing_paper_authors: Susan E., Strayer | Peter A., Heeman
raw_text: Whittaker and Stenton (1988) assigned initiative to the speaker of statements, except when it was the answer to a question, in which case it belonged to the speaker asking the question
clean_text: Whittaker and Stenton (1988) assigned initiative to the speaker of statements, except when it was the answer to a question, in which case it belonged to the speaker asking the question.

raw_text: Whittaker and Stenton (1988) proposed rules for tracking initiative based on utterance types; for example, statements, proposals, and questions show initiative, while answers and acknowledgements do not
clean_text: Whittaker and Stenton (1988) proposed rules for tracking initiative based on utterance types; for example, statements, proposals, and questions show initiative, while answers and acknowledgements do not.

raw_text: Following Whittaker and Stenton (1988), we use utterance tags to determine whether an utterance shows initiative: forward functions show initiative while others do not
clean_text: Following Whittaker and Stenton (1988), we use utterance tags to determine whether an utterance shows initiative: forward functions show initiative while others do not.

citing_paper_authors: Christine, Doran | John, Aberdeen | Laurie E., Damianos | Lynette, Hirschman
raw_text: Intuitively, it seems that control rests with the participant who is moving a conversation ahead at a given point, or selecting new topics for conversation. After experimenting with several tagging methods, we concluded that the approach presented in Walker and Whittaker (1990) adopted from (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988) best captured the aspects of the dialogue we were interested in and, as with the DAs, could be tagged reliably on our data
clean_text: After experimenting with several tagging methods, we concluded that the approach presented in Walker and Whittaker (1990) adopted from (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988) best captured the aspects of the dialogue we were interested in and, as with the DAs, could be tagged reliably on our data.

raw_text: Constructs such as Initiative and Control (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988), which attempt to operationalize the authority over a discourse? s structure, fall under the umbrella of positioning
clean_text: Constructs such as Initiative and Control (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988), which attempt to operationalize the authority over a discourse's structure, fall under the umbrella of positioning.

raw_text: A speaker who begins a discourse segment is said to have initiative, while control accounts for which speaker is being addressed in a dialogue (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988)
clean_text: A speaker who begins a discourse segment is said to have initiative, while control accounts for which speaker is being addressed in a dialogue (Whittaker and Stenton, 1988).
